title: Heating up hair science
text:
Heating up hair science 4:03pm BST - 02:11 
Researchers are applying a scientific approach to discover how much heat it takes to straighten hair without causing permanent damage. Ben Gruber reports.   
STORY: Tahira Reid loves engineering. So she decided to use that passion to study one of her biggest causes of anxiety. (SOUNDBITE) (English) TAHIRA REID, ASSISTANT PROFESSOR OF MECHANICAL ENGINEERING, PURDUE UNIVERSITY: "Being an African American woman myself, knowing the challenges, knowing the frustrations that woman have expressed about hairâ€¦ I was always wondering how we can think about this from a mechanical engineering perspective." So Reid stepped out of the salon and into her lab at Purdue University. There she teamed up with fellow researchers Amy Marconnet and Jaesik Hahn to answer this question. What is the perfect amount of heat to apply when straightening hair without causing permanent damage? (SOUNDBITE) (English) TAHIRA REID, ASSISTANT PROFESSOR OF MECHANICAL ENGINEERING, PURDUE UNIVERSITY: "We are wanting to see the point at which hair becomes permanently straightened, it's otherwise called heat damage. And if we understand the onset at which that happens than we might be able to intervene before or give some suggestions before you get to that point." (SOUNDBITE) (English) AMY MARCONNET, ASSISTANT PROFESSOR OF MECHANICAL ENGINEERING, PURDUE UNIVERSITY: "If you go to the mall right now you see an isle full of straightening irons, and they have terms like ion technology and twirling. Our question is what are these things actually doing?" The team used an infrared microscope, a heating iron attached to a robotic arm, and other hi-tech instruments, to examine hair the same way they would carbon nanotubes. (SOUNDBITE) (English) AMY MARCONNET, ASSISTANT PROFESSOR OF MECHANICAL ENGINEERING, PURDUE UNIVERSITY: "So what we can see from the IR camera is the temperature of the hair as a function of a position in time. What we are actually measuring is how the temperature evolves in the strand of hair as we move the straightening iron over it." Their preliminary results showed that the science of hair is challenging, mainly because everyone's hair is different. But the team can conclusively say that African American hair seems more susceptible to heat damage than Caucasian hair. The research is ongoing. The ultimate goal is to gather enough data to give people of different ethnic backgrounds a scientific equation on how to straighten hair.... without burning it.  //reut.rs/1MbtxvC
